intro: Calamintha barosma, commonly known as narrowleaf germander, is a perennial herb native to southern Europe and parts of western Asia. It belongs to the Lamiaceae family, which is characterized by square stems and aromatic leaves. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring opposite, narrow, lance-shaped leaves with a slightly hairy surface. Its small, tubular flowers are usually pink or purple, arranged in whorls along the upper stem. Calamintha barosma is often used in traditional medicine for its mild antiseptic and carminative properties.
